abstract.text: An object that renders a scene into a custom Metal rendering pipeline and drives the scene update cycle.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: allows an app to mix SpriteKit and Metal content by rendering an
into a Metal command buffer. The reasons an app may do this instead of displaying a scene in
Apps that are built in Metal can mix in SpriteKit content. While it’s possible to add
as a subview to a Metal view, plugging
into their Metal pipeline allows layering SpriteKit content at a specific z-position.

You might be writing a SpriteKit app and decide later to take full control over some portion of renderering by implementing it with Metal, yet continue to use SpriteKit for the rest of the app. For example, you might write the environmental effects layer of your app that does fog, clouds, and rain, with custom Metal shaders, and continue to layer content below and above that with SpriteKit.

abstract.text: A visual WatchKit element that displays a SpriteKit scene.
Add high-performance 2D content with smooth animations to your app, or create a game with a high-level set of 2D game-based tools.
An object that renders a scene into a custom Metal rendering pipeline and drives the scene update cycle.
Initializes with a specific GPU to render into.
The scene this renderer will draw into the Metal command buffer.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the view displays the number of drawing passes it needed to render the view.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the view displays information about physics fields in the scene.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the view displays an overlay that shows physics bodies that are visible in the scene.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the view displays physics-related debugging information.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the view displays the number of rectangles used to render the scene.
An object that organizes all of the active SpriteKit content.
A view subclass that renders a SpriteKit scene.
Compare the different ways to display a SpriteKit scene.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
Create a renderer by specifying a GPU and then set its scene.
Draw the renderer’s scene into a custom Metal rendering pipeline.
Control when the scene’s delegate functions are called.
Control hints that have performance implications which are unique to your app.
Display metrics in the bottom corner of the scene’s frame for debugging purposes.
